Knights' first loss to Fla. Southern in OT

No. 3 Florida Southern handed second-ranked Bellarmine itsfirst loss Saturday night with a 101-96 decision in overtime at Knights Hall.

Knights' first loss to Fla. Southern in OT

By Kenzie Winstead, Special to The Courier-Journal 11:46 p.m. EST December 13, 2014

Bellarmine guard, guard Rusty Troutman (5) drives around Florida Southern forward, Stephen Battle (30) on his way to the goal. December 13, 2014.(Photo: Matt Herp, Special to the C-J)

CONNECT 1 TWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

In a game that turned into a free-throw shooting contest, No. 3 Florida Southern slipped past No. 2 Bellarmine 101-96 in overtime Saturday night at Knights Hall in the Bellarmine Classic.

The Moccasins (8-0), a powerhouse in Division II, hit 38 of 45 free throws, including 17 of 18 in the last 8:17 of the game, to hold off the host Knights.

Bellarmine, meanwhile, connected on 24 of 34 at the free-throw line.

Despite the gap in free throws, the Knights had their chances at the end of overtime but George Suggs missed a couple of 3-point shots in the last 25 seconds.

    Even in defeat, Bellarmine coach Scott Davenport said he's still high as ever on his team.

    "That's a great basketball game with two great teams playing as hard as they can play," Davenport said. "The crowd was super. The kids played their hearts out. What are you going to do."

    Florida Southern now has won 26 straight games against non-conference opponents during the regular season and own two wins against No. 2-ranked teams this season. They also beat power Metro State earlier.

    "I don't feel one bit different about this basketball team than if we had won by one point — not one bit," Davenport said. "If we win by one point, everyone's in total celebration. We played the same. We've got to move forward and get ready for Fairmont State (Saturday afternoon)."

    Jake Thelen kept the Knights (7-1) close with a career-high 29 points and 15 rebounds. He hit 13 of 16 shots.

    Thelen said he's only concerned about winning.

    "Individual stuff doesn't matter," Thelen said. "We lost the game and we had plenty of opportunities to win the game. It had nothing to do with the refs. They were calling it both ways. ... Tomorrow, it's out of our minds and we'll get ready for Fairmont State."

    COURIER-JOURNAL

    Tim Sullivan | Kentucky men's basketball team finds way to win without whining

    Bellarmine led 39-34 at the half but the Mocassins came out after the break and scored the first seven points. From there, the second half and overtime went back and forth.

    At the end of regulation, Bellarmine's Rusty Troutman, who hit 13 of 16 free throws, hit both at the line with 7.6 seconds left.

    Florida Southern's Kevin Capers, who led the Moccasins with 25 points, missed a 10-footer with two seconds left.

    In overtime, Florida Southern's Stephen Battle — who finished with 21 points —completed an old-fashioned three-point play, giving the Moccasins a 97-94 lead with 1:59 left.

    Then Bellarmine's Chris Whitehead hit what appeared to be a 3-pointer with 1:27 left but the officials looked at the monitor and changed it to a 2-point bucket. Bellarmine still trailed 97-96.

    AND: Martin's lessons from parents pay off at Butler

    Bellarmine, though, couldn't keep Florida Southern off the free-throw line.

    The Moccasins iced the game by hitting their last four free throws.

    Besides Thelen, Troutman added 18 points for the Knights. Whitehead had 17 points and 12 assists.

    The Knights were hampered when starter Josh Derksen fouled out with 5:56 left in regulation. He finished with 10 points.

    "I wasn't happy with myself," he said. "After that, I just tried to support everybody as best I could."

    Derksen said he believes the loss will help.

    "I think we'll learn from it," he said. "We'll come back hungrier, if anything. I'm looking forward to practice this week."

    Davenport pointed to turnovers. The Knights committed 23.

    "Nobody tried to turn it over," he said. "Nobody tried to miss a free throw. The kids played their hearts out. I don't feel one bit different about them.

    "This is going to hurt for a day but we've got to come in Monday and get better," Davenport said.

    Southern Indiana 84, Ohio Valley (W.Va.) 83: New Albany product TeNale Roland poured in 27 points to lead the Screaming Eagles (6-1) past the Fighting Scots (0-8) in Saturday's first Bellarmine Classic game.

    Roland hit 8 of 12 shots and all six of his free throws.

    George Edwards added 20 points for Southern Indiana. Robert Smelser had 28 for Ohio Valley.

    FLORIDA SOUTHERN 101, BELLARMINE 96

    FLORIDA SOUTHERN (8-0) - Capers 5-16 13-14 25, Battle 8-16 5-5 21, Kelly 5-11 8-11 19, Volovic 3-7 7-8 16, Logan 4-7 0-0 11, Johnson 0-3 3-4 3, Travis 1-7 1-1 3, Williams 1-4 0-0 2, Turner 0-1 1-2 1, Ross 0-0 0-0 0. Totals 27-72 38-45 101.

    BELLARMINE (7-1) - Thelen 13-16 3-6 29, Ru. Troutman 2-8 13-16 18, Whitehead 7-12 3-5 17, Sewell 6-9 0-0 13, Derksen 3-8 2-2 10, Suggs 1-4 3-5 6, Parrish 1-3 0-0 3, Bach 0-0 0-0 0, Landry 0-0 0-0 0, Maynard 0-1 0-0 0. Totals 33-61 24-34 96.

    Halftime - Bellarmine 39-34. End of Regulation - tied at 84-84. 3-point goals - Florida Southern 9-27 (Logan 3-5, Volovic 3-4, Capers 2-5, Kelly 1-5, Williams 0-2, Turner 0-1, Travis 0-4, Battle 0-1), Bellarmine 6-18 (Derksen 2-5, Sewell 1-1, Parrish 1-1, Suggs 1-4, Ru. Troutman 1-5, Maynard 0-1, Whitehead 0-1). Fouled out - Johnson, Derksen, Ru. Troutman, Sewell. Rebounds - Florida Southern 43 (Kelly 10), Bellarmine 40 (Thelen 15). Assists - Florida Southern 12 (Travis, Capers 3 each), Bellarmine 20 (Whitehead 12). Total fouls - Florida Southern 30, Bellarmine 31. Technical fouls - Logan. A - 1,879.
